Is it okay to practice meditation from two different Buddhist traditions at the same time?

Generally yes, especially early on — many people explore before settling into one approach.

The main caution: some teachers advise against mixing certain advanced practices. Different deity yoga systems, for instance, can have instructions that actively conflict. Different tantric lineages structure visualization and mantra practice in ways that don't layer well.

At the level of basic shamatha and vipassana, though, different traditions' approaches are mostly compatible. Sitting with the breath is sitting with the breath whether you learned it from a Theravada teacher or a Zen teacher.

The practical question is whether you have a teacher in either tradition, and whether they know you're also practicing elsewhere. Most good teachers will be honest about where mixing helps and where it creates confusion. If you don't have a teacher yet, exploring different traditions is actually a reasonable way to find one.
But I've read that the Rime movement in Tibet combined all traditions, so isn't mixing always fine?

The Rime movement is often misunderstood as a "mix everything" approach. It wasn't.

Jamgon Kongtrul and Jamyang Khyentse Wangpo were deeply trained masters who studied multiple lineages to preserve teachings that were being lost. They understood the internal logic of each system well enough to know what was compatible and what wasn't. Their non-sectarian approach was about respecting and preserving distinct lineages, not blending them into one practice.

So "Rime did it" isn't quite a green light for combining practices without understanding them. It's more like: they had the depth to navigate multiple traditions because they understood each one thoroughly.

For most practitioners, the honest answer is: start with one approach, go deep enough to understand its internal logic, and then you'll be better equipped to evaluate whether adding practices from another tradition will help or create confusion. Your teacher is the right person to navigate this with you.

My friend says Buddhism teaches that women have lower rebirth than men. Is this true?

Your friend is pointing at something real in the textual record, even if the conclusion is more complicated than that.

Some traditional Buddhist texts do contain passages reflecting the gender biases of their historical context. There are references in certain suttas to female birth as less fortunate, and the early monastic code imposed more rules on nuns than monks. These aren't fabrications — they're in the canon.

At the same time, the Buddha himself affirmed women's capacity for full awakening, and many lineages have produced extraordinary female practitioners and teachers. The Prajnaparamita tradition personifies the highest wisdom as female. Yeshe Tsogyal, Machig Labdron, and many others are central figures, not footnotes.

The honest position: Buddhism's textual tradition contains both genuine egalitarian potential and genuine patriarchal residue. Different teachers handle this differently — some argue the problematic passages are cultural artifacts, others engage in more complex hermeneutics. The Dalai Lama and many contemporary Kagyu and Zen teachers explicitly reject gender hierarchy.

What your friend found is real. What they concluded from it isn't the whole picture.
So is Buddhism sexist or not?

Both, depending on what you mean by "Buddhism."

If you mean the full historical institution across 2,500 years and dozens of cultures — yes, it has participated in patriarchal norms, sometimes vigorously. Nuns in some Theravada countries still can't get full ordination. That's not ancient history.

If you mean the core philosophical framework — dependent origination, emptiness, the possibility of awakening — there's nothing inherently gendered in it. Suffering doesn't check your chromosomes.

The useful question isn't "is Buddhism sexist" as a yes/no, but "which parts of the tradition perpetuate harm, and which parts contain tools for liberation that are genuinely available to everyone?" Living Buddhist teachers are actively wrestling with exactly this question, and they don't all agree.

Anyone who tells you Buddhism is purely progressive is whitewashing the record. Anyone who tells you it's irredeemably patriarchal is ignoring the philosophical core and the many women who've found genuine freedom through practice.

Can meditation cure my depression?

It helps many people. It's not a cure in the clinical sense, and treating it as one can actually cause harm.

Here's what the research actually shows: mindfulness-based interventions (particularly MBCT — mindfulness-based cognitive therapy) have solid evidence for preventing depressive relapse in people who've had three or more episodes. For acute major depression, the evidence is weaker and more mixed.

Here's what the research also shows but gets talked about less: some people with depression experience worsening symptoms during intensive meditation practice. Concentration practices can amplify rumination. Certain retreat settings strip away the coping mechanisms and social contact that are keeping someone functional.

The practical advice: meditation works best as part of a larger approach, not as a replacement for professional support. If you're currently depressed, a therapist who understands both meditation and clinical depression is worth more than a meditation app. If you're in remission and want to build resilience, a regular practice can genuinely help.

Anyone who tells you meditation definitely cures depression is selling something. Anyone who tells you it's useless for mental health is ignoring real evidence. The honest answer is in between, and it depends on where you are right now.
My meditation teacher says that depression is just attachment and I should meditate through it rather than take medication.

That's dangerous advice, and I want to be direct about why.

Clinical depression involves neurochemistry, not just mental habits. Telling someone with major depressive disorder to "meditate through it" is like telling someone with a broken leg to visualize healing. The framing of depression as "just attachment" flattens a complex medical condition into a spiritual failure.

Many respected Buddhist teachers — including the Dalai Lama, Mingyur Rinpoche (who has spoken openly about his own anxiety), and others — support the use of medication when it's clinically indicated. Medication can create the stability that makes practice possible.

This doesn't mean your teacher is a bad person or that everything they teach is wrong. It means they're outside their competence on this specific point. Meditation teachers are not mental health professionals unless they also hold that training.

If you're dealing with depression: please talk to a mental health professional, not just a meditation teacher. You can do both. They're not in conflict. And if a teacher frames seeking professional help as spiritual weakness, that tells you something about the teacher's limitations, not yours.

Is Buddhism compatible with science? I keep hearing that Buddhism is 'the most scientific religion.'

That claim is popular but oversimplified, and it does a disservice to both Buddhism and science.

There are genuine points of convergence: Buddhist epistemology values empirical investigation, the Buddha's advice to test teachings against experience resonates with empirical methodology, and contemplative practices are producing interesting neuroscience research.

But Buddhism also contains claims that don't fit scientific methodology: rebirth across lifetimes, the existence of various realms of existence, specific karmic mechanisms, and certain cosmological claims. These aren't marginal footnotes — they're structurally important to many Buddhist traditions.

The "most scientific religion" framing usually works by cherry-picking the philosophical parts that align with modern secular values and quietly setting aside the parts that don't. It also implicitly treats science as the gold standard that religion needs to measure up to, which is its own assumption worth examining.

A more honest framing: Buddhism and science overlap in some areas, diverge in others, and ask different kinds of questions. The contemplative tradition has genuine insights about the nature of mind and suffering that science is beginning to investigate. And Buddhism has metaphysical commitments that go beyond what empirical science can confirm or deny.

That's less catchy than "most scientific religion," but it's more accurate.
So should I just ignore the rebirth stuff and treat Buddhism as a philosophy?

You can. Many people do, and they get genuine benefit from the ethical framework and meditation practices. Stephen Batchelor's "secular Buddhism" is a whole approach built on this.

But I'd suggest a middle path: rather than either believing in rebirth because a tradition says so, or dismissing it because it doesn't fit your current worldview, you could hold it as an open question.

The practical teachings on suffering, impermanence, and interdependence work regardless of your position on rebirth. You don't need to believe in literal reincarnation for the Four Noble Truths to be useful. But some practitioners find that as their practice deepens, their relationship to these questions shifts in unexpected ways.

The risk of the "just philosophy" approach: it can become another way of staying comfortable, keeping practice at the level of self-improvement rather than genuine transformation. Many teachers would say that's fine as a starting point, but it's not the full scope of what's available.

Start where you are. Practice honestly. See what happens. That's more productive than resolving the metaphysics first.

Can I learn tantra from books without a teacher?

You can learn about tantra from books. You can't safely practice most tantric methods without a teacher.

This isn't gatekeeping mysticism — there are practical reasons. Tantric practices involve working with visualization, energy, mantra, and sometimes intense psychological material. Without guidance, it's genuinely possible to destabilize yourself. The teacher-student relationship in tantra isn't ceremonial; it's functional. The teacher monitors what's happening and adjusts the practice.

There are things books can give you: historical context, philosophical framework, an understanding of what tantra is and isn't, and the ability to evaluate whether a particular teacher or lineage is worth your time. Reginald Ray, Judith Simmer-Brown, and Rob Preece have all written accessible and honest introductions.

But the actual practices — deity yoga, completion stage work, the specific visualizations and mantras — these are designed to be transmitted personally. And there are real examples of people who tried to DIY tantric practice and ran into serious psychological difficulty.

The honest path: read widely, find a qualified teacher, and be patient. If a book or website claims to give you the complete tantric path without a teacher, that's a red flag about the source, not an invitation to try.
That sounds like organized religion trying to maintain control over spiritual knowledge.

I understand why it looks that way, and you're not wrong that some institutions have used secrecy to maintain power. That's a real pattern and worth being skeptical about.

But here's the counterargument from experience rather than authority: tantric practices actually do produce intense psychological effects. This isn't theoretical. People who've done unsupervised intensive visualization practices have experienced dissociation, anxiety, and psychotic-like episodes. The Cheetah House project at Brown University documents meditation-related adverse effects, and some of the worst cases involve unsupervised tantric-adjacent practices.

So the question isn't really "is this gatekeeping" — it's "does working with a qualified guide produce better outcomes than going alone?" And the evidence says yes, particularly for practices that deliberately intensify psychological experience.

There's also a middle ground: many teachers offer teachings quite openly now. Livestreamed teachings, accessible preliminary practices, and open meditation instruction are more available than ever. The "you need a teacher" part isn't about restricting access to information — it's about having someone who can help when things get difficult.

Be skeptical of any teacher who uses secrecy primarily to create mystique or dependency. But also be skeptical of the assumption that all knowledge is equally safe to apply without guidance. Some things genuinely benefit from apprenticeship. Tantra is one of them.

Is karma the same as fate? If everything is determined by karma, what's the point of trying?

Karma isn't fate. This is one of the most common and most consequential misunderstandings.

Fate means your future is fixed and you can't change it. Karma means your actions have consequences — including the action you're taking right now. It's closer to "momentum" than "destiny." Past actions create conditions, but present actions can change direction.

The fatalistic version — "they're suffering because of their karma" — is actually a distortion that's been used to justify caste systems, victim-blaming, and passivity. Many Buddhist teachers actively push back on this reading.

Here's the part that often gets lost: karma in Buddhist understanding is primarily about intention, not just outcome. The mental state behind an action matters as much as the action itself. This means you're not locked into a predetermined script — every moment of genuine intention creates new conditions.

So "what's the point of trying" actually has a direct answer: trying IS the point. The effort you make right now is itself karma — it's creating conditions for what comes next. The present moment is always available for change, regardless of what came before.

That said, karma in Buddhist philosophy is described as extremely complex — the Buddha reportedly said only a fully awakened being could trace all karmic connections. So simple cause-and-effect narratives ("you did X so Y happened to you") are usually reductive.
